review_title: A dynamic organization and a driven, talented and effective staff.
pros: My experience with Internews is from the business admin side.  It is a very well-run nonprofit organization that has grown considerably in the last decade and continues to evolve and expand in exciting ways!  As an employee, you will work with people all over the map working on all kinds of interesting projects.  Everyone in the organization I have worked with so far has been friendly, professional, and effective at what they do.
cons: Because it is a nonprofit, many jobs with Internews are highly funding-dependent, which is not ideal if you are looking for job security.  It is also worth keeping in mind that it can be a demanding and fast-paced work environment, which is energizing for some people but might be draining for others.

pros: Pay is higher on average in comparison to competitors and like-minded orgs. There are some truly brilliant and friendly folks working at Internews, especially those based at its field offices. Culture is laidback (e.g. wearing jeans on Monday is normal, most people are encouraged to work home on Fridays, frequent happy hours).
cons: Internews prizes itself on being women-led and “inclusive”. But how inclusive are you really if you only have 5 people of color (in an office of 70 staff) working at your headquarters in DC? Given that one of its missions is to promote the voices of minorities abroad, it’s a shame that this value isn’t reflected in both management and non-management. From personal observation, this isn’t the most pleasant environment for ethnic minorities given the prevalence of microaggressions that are casually written off or dismissed as simply jokes. Supervisors do not receive proper training in managing people. HR genuinely seems to care for employees but is heavily understaffed.

review_title: Wonderful mission, little room for growth
pros: The mission to strengthen journalism across various media and around the world, especially in harsh contexts, is incredibly unique and necessary. It is a wonderful mission that most staff feel passionately about. Content is cross-functional so you are exposed to a variety of social issues. Internews works around the world and they are dedicated to real social change. They pay marginally better than most NGOs of similar size.
cons: If you work in any of the field locations or are mid or senior management, there is next to zero work-life balance. People love what they do, but when they do nothing but that it really results in a lack of creativity and inability to experiment and learn. There is a lot of lip service to these concepts, but not much leadership to support staff in terms of professional development and more say in what the organization prioritizes.

pros: Great, passionate, female-led organization with deep commitment to creating positive change in the world. Flexible schedules, laid back office, great benefits. Pay is better than average for most positions. Opportunities for advancement for strong performers. Inclusive and friendly culture.
cons: Project funding in the NGO world in general makes job security in this sector challenging - many positions are based on direct funds availability which is donor dependent. Projects are often based in some of the most difficult locations in the world which is challenging.

pros: Dynamic, meeting many people, interesting topics, work with the youth and inspiring young people, mentoring
cons: Low salary, long work hours, unequal treatment of employees, management incapable of solving problems or offering any advice, discrimination based on gender and nationality, management easily manipulated by certain employees, harassment at work without any improvement even after reporting to management, four people left the project due to harassment- two of them were seeking for psychological help, no chance for travel and progress, employees asked to do personal shopping for management, management not capable of providing a timely reference after the expiry of the project thus employees miss out on opportunities.

review_title: Proceed with Caution - at least at the Africa Regional Hub
pros:
I worked with the Africa regional team. 

- Compared to other International NGOs working in the Development and Humanitarian space in Africa, Internews has a relatively small team and a growing portfolio so opportunities for growth and exposure to new areas of work are plenty. I say this with a caveat because it required initiative and given the organisational politics, favoritism sometimes played a role as to which staff accessed growth opportunities.
- Passionate and talented team members and managers in some of the country programs
- Busy work but flexible working arrangements possible
cons:
- Uninspiring and dare I say immature Africa Regional Director who did not seem to understand that leadership requires more than technical knowledge. Increasingly toxic environment under his leadership - including publicly disrespecting staff, gossip and back-stabbing. 

- Very poor HR practices and low investment in HR systems and structures at field level. HR staff at field level mostly non-existence, leaving senior managers and staff at the Nairobi regional hub who had limited HR technical expertise

- Recruitment practices at the field level - depending on hiring manager - are laughable. Cronyism is common and contrary to popular belief about Africa and Africans, an expatriate senior manager was particularly prone to hiring and re-hiring his friends and acquaintances. 

- For all its talk of low tolerance of abuse and gender equality, Internews seems to condone and cover abuse of its staff. A senior manager telling a female staff member that perhaps the reason why her male colleague acted inappropriately was because she is beautiful is mind-blowing to say the least.

- Seems to be a disconnect between the HQ and the regional and field level staff
